body:
### Problem

There already exist multiples plugins that handle progress report ([noice](https://github.com/folke/noice.nvim) or [fidget](https://github.com/j-hui/fidget.nvim) comes to mind). Progress report is currently only used by LSPs in core so for other plugins that would want to report progress, they need to either fake being an LSP or use the private APIs.

Some other usages of progress report APIs could be:
- progress of external formatters (https://github.com/stevearc/conform.nvim/issues/250 -> workaround available relying on `noice.lsp.progress`)
- progress of external linters (https://github.com/mfussenegger/nvim-lint/issues/366 -> api available you can hook yourself on a plugin)
- progress of task runners plugins or user tasks (`git push` and co for example)

### Expected behavior

Provide a `vim.ui.progress` that could look like this:

```
vim.ui.progress({opts})
    Starts progress report of an asynchronous action.

    Example: >lua
        local handle = vim.ui.progress({ name = 'Git push'' })
        -- provide updates while the task is runnig
        handle:update({ subtext = "subtext"})
        handle:update({ percent = 75 })
        -- task succeeded, clear progress report
        handle:complete()
        -- or signal a failure
        handle:fail("error message")
<

    Parameters:
      • {opts}        (`table`) Additional options.
                      • name (string) Name of the long running task
                      • subtext (string|nil) Description/name of the subtask
                      • percent (int|nil) If not null, percentage of progress of the task.

    Returns:
      • {handle}        (`table`) Handle to update the task.
             • update (function(opts)) Change displayed information
                          • name (string|nil) Name of the long running task
                          • subtext (string|nil) Description/name of the subtask
                          • percent (int|nil) If not null, percentage of progress of the task.
             • complete (function) Mark task as successfull & remove it
             • fail (function(string)) Mark task as failed, send an error message & remove the task
```

comment_data.body:
+1. Added to https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/32084
Related: 

- https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/28809

Getting the interface right is the main thing needed here, the implementation can be lifted from an existing plugin (why don't these plugins upstream stuff?). Your outline looks decent.

- should `complete`/`fail` be a single function like `stop(status:'success'|'fail'|'cancel')` ?
- do we need `cancel()` ? 
- `subtext` => `desc`
- (orthogonal?) By default, `CTRL-c` should cancel whatever is in-progress.


The [vscode Progress interface](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-extension-samples/blob/main/progress-sample/README.md) is also worth a look.

I'd like to throw a small note into the API design of something like this:
Please allow quantifying progress as `#steps / #total` instead of only `%percentage completed`.

For a user of the API that wants percentage, that can always be done trivially by setting `total = 100`.
For a lot of other common cases:
 - `#tests run / #total number of tests`
 - `bytes read / total size`
 - `# files checked / # total files`

I think `#steps / #total` would be better, because that way, when progress is slow, it's easier to distinguish if it's due to a large total number of steps, or due to one specific step taking very long.
Plus, users of the API wouldn't be forced to convert to percentage (meaning less plumbing for the user, as the API or the UI could take care of it).
Also, in some cases it can be useful to allow updating the total (more steps detected while the task is running).

```
    • update (function(opts)) Change displayed information
        • name (string|nil) Name of the long running task
        • subtext (string|nil) Description/name of the subtask
        • progress (int|float|nil) If not null, current progress of the task.
          If total is null, this is interpreted as percentage.
        • total (int|float|nil) If not null, total number of steps in the task.
          If null, progress is interpreted as a percentage.
```
```lua
        local handle = vim.ui.progress({ name = 'Testing' })
        handle:update({ subtext = "Running my_tests.lua:my_test()..."})
        handle:update({ progress = 1, total =  4}) -- Render as "1/4" or "25%"
```

I'd like to propose a bit different, more "flat" design. Although nothing majorly wrong with returning a special object after initiating progress, it (arguably) has several issues:
- Requires a dedicated design. Not bad per se, but trying to reuse existing approaches might be better.
- Can be harder for users/plugins to override/reimplement. I assume this is meant to be overridable by plugins (like `vim.ui.select()`, `vim.ui.input()`, `vim.notify()`), so this should be taken into account.
- Leads to more convoluted tests, as it would require transferring all test code to be executed in child process.

The suggestion mostly reuses already existing approaches of [LSP `workDoneProgress`](https://microsoft.github.io/language-server-protocol/specifications/lsp/3.17/specification/#workDoneProgressReport) and loosely some basic Nvim's API/Lua functions (`nvim_buf_set_extmark()`, `vim.diagnostic.set()`, etc.). It can look something like this:

```lua
--- @param ns_id integer Namespace for progress source. Implementations can
---   use to display information about the source (like name of LSP server)
---   based on namespace's name. Can also be a string directly.
--- @param token integer|string Token to identify specific progress report
---   within namespace.
--- @param kind 'begin'|'report'|'end' Stage of progress. Can also have `'fail'` if needed.
--- @param opts? { title: string?, cancellable: boolean?, message: string?, percentage: integer? }
---   Notes:
---   - `title` is required for `'begin'` kind.
---   - `message` can be used to show more detailed `#done / #total` progress,
---     as is currently done by LSP servers.
vim.ui.progress = function(ns_id, token, kind, opts) end
```

Hi, I was wondering about this as well and started a proof of concept plugin/api.. 

The idea I have is that neovim should be progress "broker", to decouple progress source/event from progress visualization.
This api would allow to have "levels" or "categories" to which progress sources could direct the event to, and with them, specific visualizations for each.

For example, LSP workDoneProgress events are "global" in a sense that a user would want to always see it. There are also progress events that only have meaning to a single buffer, like clangd's fileStatus event.

If the api in the plugin where to exist in neovim, I think it could be like this

Create a progress viewer/display:
```lua
local display = vim.progress.create_display({ --[[categories]]  }, { on_start = function(event)  end, on_update = function(event) end, on_end = function(event) end }) 

```

Send progress event:
```lua
local event = vim.progress.create_event(srcid, category, { title = '...', --[[additional data]] })
vim.progress.event_start(event)
-- ...
vim.progress.event_update(event, { message = '..', progress = 0.4 })
-- ...
vim.progress.event_end(event, { message = '..' , --[[...]] })
```

This [plugin](https://github.com/drehren/fltprogr.nvim) implements a similar idea.
